lines.content: This file records how I used AI tools to support development for this project.
For several methods (e.g., deleteTask, markTask, parser-related methods), I first designed and implemented the basic test cases myself (e.g., normal valid input).
After that, I asked ChatGPT to help generate additional test cases covering:
- invalid inputs (e.g., negative index, out-of-range index)
AI was mainly used to brainstorm edge cases and variations for the same method to improve coverage.
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Pok√©mon _Wooper_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/wooper.Wooper.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run wooper.Wooper.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
